pageProps.contentHtml:
construction, weak convergence

Let dμn\diff\mu_ndμn​ be a sequence of probability measures on [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1] so that

∫f(x) dμn(x)\int f\p{x} \,\diff\mu_n\p{x}∫f(x)dμn​(x)

converges for every continuous function f ⁣:[0,1]→R\func{f}{\br{0,1}}{\R}f:[0,1]→R.

  1. Show that

    ∬g(x,y) dμn(x) dμn(y)\iint g\p{x, y} \,\diff\mu_n\p{x} \,\diff\mu_n\p{y}∬g(x,y)dμn​(x)dμn​(y)

    converges for every continuous g ⁣:[0,1]2→R\func{g}{\br{0,1}^2}{\R}g:[0,1]2→R.

  2. Show by example that under the above hypotheses, it is possible that

    ∬{0≤x≤y≤1} dμn(x) dμn(y)\iint_{\set{0 \leq x \leq y \leq 1}} \,\diff\mu_n\p{x} \,\diff\mu_n\p{y}∬{0≤x≤y≤1}​dμn​(x)dμn​(y)

    does not converge.
Solution.

  1. By Stone-Weierstrass, the set

    A={∑k=1nfk(x)gk(y) | n∈N, fk,gk∈C([0,1])}A = \set{\sum_{k=1}^n f_k\p{x}g_k\p{y} \st n \in \N,\ f_k, g_k \in C\p{\br{0,1}}}A={k=1∑n​fk​(x)gk​(y)∣∣​n∈N, fk​,gk​∈C([0,1])}

    is dense in C([0,1]2)C\p{\br{0,1}^2}C([0,1]2). Hence, by applying weak convergence and Fubini's theorem, we see that μn⊗μn\mu_n \otimes \mu_nμn​⊗μn​ converges weakly-* to μ⊗μ\mu \otimes \muμ⊗μ.

  2. Let μn=δ0\mu_n = \delta_0μn​=δ0​ if nnn is odd and μn=1n∑k=1nδk/n2\mu_n = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^n \delta_{k/n^2}μn​=n1​∑k=1n​δk/n2​ for nnn even. Then for nnn even and ggg is continuous,

    ∫g(x) dμn(x)=1n∑k=1ng(kn2)→n→∞g(0),\int g\p{x} \,\diff\mu_n\p{x} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^n g\p{\frac{k}{n^2}} \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} g\p{0},∫g(x)dμn​(x)=n1​k=1∑n​g(n2k​)n→∞​g(0),

    by continuity, and it's clear that the same holds for the odd terms. However, for nnn od, we have

    ∫{0≤x≤y≤1}dμn(x) dμn(y)=0\int_{\set{0 \leq x \leq y \leq 1}} \diff\mu_n\p{x} \,\diff\mu_n\p{y} = 0∫{0≤x≤y≤1}​dμn​(x)dμn​(y)=0

    and for nnn even,

    ∫{0≤x≤y≤1}dμn(x) dμn(y)=∫01∫0ydμn(x) dμn(y)=∑j=1n2∫[j−1n2,jn2)∫0ydμn(x) dμn(y)=∑j=1n∫[j−1n2,jn2)jn dμn(y)+∑j=n+1n2∫[j−1n2,jn2)nn dμn(y)=∑j=1njn2=n+12n→n→∞12,\begin{aligned} \int_{\set{0 \leq x \leq y \leq 1}} \diff\mu_n\p{x} \,\diff\mu_n\p{y} &= \int_0^1 \int_0^y \diff\mu_n\p{x} \,\diff\mu_n\p{y} \\ &= \sum_{j=1}^{n^2} \int_{\pco{\frac{j-1}{n^2}, \frac{j}{n^2}}} \int_0^y \diff\mu_n\p{x} \,\diff\mu_n\p{y} \\ &= \sum_{j=1}^n \int_{\pco{\frac{j-1}{n^2}, \frac{j}{n^2}}} \frac{j}{n} \,\diff\mu_n\p{y} + \sum_{j=n+1}^{n^2} \int_{\pco{\frac{j-1}{n^2}, \frac{j}{n^2}}} \frac{n}{n} \,\diff\mu_n\p{y} \\ &= \sum_{j=1}^n \frac{j}{n^2} \\ &= \frac{n + 1}{2n} \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} \frac{1}{2}, \end{aligned}∫{0≤x≤y≤1}​dμn​(x)dμn​(y)​=∫01​∫0y​dμn​(x)dμn​(y)=j=1∑n2​∫[n2j−1​,n2j​)​∫0y​dμn​(x)dμn​(y)=j=1∑n​∫[n2j−1​,n2j​)​nj​dμn​(y)+j=n+1∑n2​∫[n2j−1​,n2j​)​nn​dμn​(y)=j=1∑n​n2j​=2nn+1​n→∞​21​,​

    so the sequence diverges.
